last_post.content: This is a really great tool (that doesn’t require any account permissions) which produces an ordered list of accounts your mutual followers follow that you don’t yet follow: https://followgraph.vercel.app #Mastodon #Fediverse

1/ A lot of people have been asking for an explainer on what is going on with Southwest Airlines and the massive meltdown that occurred. Hi, I'm TProphet. I write the Seat 31B travel blog (https://www.seat31b.com) and closely follow the airline industry. More importantly, I have a friend whom Southwest abandoned in Las Vegas until New Year's (along with his cat), and there was literally nothing I could do for him. Ready? Let's dive in.

#Receptiogate is truly an unbelievable story. What starts out as a pretty appalling case of plagiarism turns out to be a far bigger operation. I hope it gets fully investigated because what we are seeing must be just the tip of the iceberg. Start here: https://mssprovenance.blogspot.com/2022/12/nobody-cares-about-your-blog.html

One of the things I would miss here on Mastodon was all of the alerts from my local infrastructure and government twitter accounts. These will likely take a very long time to make the migration.

With https://bird.makeup, you can create bot accounts that put those tweets in your Mastodon timeline. For instance, I follow the Washington State Patrol account for regional weather related road closures and accident reports:

@wspd7pio

EDIT: I Should have tagged the project's creator: @vincent

title: Class Action Targets Experian Over Account Security – Krebs on Security

last_post.content:
Notified Experian on Dec. 23 that their site was allowing anyone to see the credit report for, well, basically anyone, completely bypassing their lame 4-5 multiple guess questions and other security.

Or even in cases (like mine) where trying to get your credit report generates an error saying you have 3 other options for getting your free report from them (calling, mailing, or chat w/ rep). The site said Experian didn't have enough info to validate my identity, but when I changed the url slightly, it showed me my entire report. Glad I checked, too, because the info in there is so completely wrong I don't even know where to start.

So it's Dec. 27, and I still haven't heard anything from Experian. All you needed was the person's name, address, SSN and DOB. This info has been exposed on pretty much most Americans for many years now.

BTW, I checked this with several friends who volunteered to check their own reports, and they were able to fully replicate what I did.

It's bad enough that we can't stop companies like Experian from making $2B a quarter collecting and selling our info, but there has to be some real accountability. And as we saw with the Equifax settlement, class-actions and more laughable "credit monitoring" services aren't going to cut it.

Experian has shown this year especially that it gives exactly zero fscks about securing access to the data that drives its entire business.

https://krebsonsecurity.com/2022/08/class-action-targets-experian-over-account-security/

https://krebsonsecurity.com/2022/07/experian-you-have-some-explaining-to-do/

https://krebsonsecurity.com/2021/04/experian-api-exposed-credit-scores-of-most-americans/

title: GitHub - hodgesmr/mastodon_digest: A Python script that aggregates recent popular posts from your Mastodon timeline

last_post.content:
Here it is! My algorithmic #Mastodon Digest is now #OpenSource! It surfaces posts and boosts from your home timeline that you may have missed. You need a bit of comfort running #python #projects but I tried to make it as turnkey as possible. Everything runs locally, and you can currently generate 288 different digests based on your preferred:
• Timeline history
• Scoring criteria
• Threshold criteria

Lots more to experiment with — please remember this is still a toy 😄

https://github.com/hodgesmr/mastodon_digest

Someone has made, and uploaded, a feature comparison of over twenty Mastodon apps.

I'd like to repeat that THIS IS NOT MY LIST. I didn't create or upload it, and have no control over its contents or accuracy. And because the apps are updated frequently, parts of it WILL be inaccurate.

#mastodon

https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1De5KRwqMIdwEryfoeBLARgxF7QgKkeOQBCilKuIdAXE/edit#gid=0

Fission is in the news, but few recognize that a woman physicist was behind the discovery.

Lise Meitner’s brilliance led to the discovery of nuclear fission. But her long time collaborator Otto Hahn, was awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry w/o her in 1944, even though she had given the first theoretical explanation.

Albert Einstein called Meitner “our Marie Curie." She also adamantly refused to work on the atomic bomb during WWII. https://www.aps.org/publications/apsnews/201502/physicshistory.cfm #women #history #science #energy

title: Government announces Passivhaus standards to be adopted in Scotland

last_post.content:
I don't think this is getting the coverage it needs. Scottish government to require passivhaus standard for all new build homes. This is big. Really big. Growing out of lessons from the 70's oil crisis. Passivhaus buildings use very little energy to heat, or to cool. We've known how to do this for decades. It's gross negligence from all western governments that the same is not true of all new builds in the developed world.

https://www.thenational.scot/news/23197204.government-announces-passivhaus-standards-adopted-scotland/

title: Amazon Packages Burn in India, Last Stop in Broken Plastic Recycling System

last_post.content:
For years I’ve wondered how it’s economical to sift through all the literal garbage and various plastics people throw into recycling bins to then recycle some subset.

It turns out it isn’t and a lot of “recycling” in the U.S. ended up being sent to landfills in China & India instead.

When I first found out was akin to a Santa Claus isn’t real moment.

https://www.bloomberg.com/features/2022-india-plastic-recycling-pollution/

title: Twitter rival Mastodon rejects funding to protect non-profit status

last_post.content:
Glad to see @Gargron turning down VC funding for Mastodon. The #1 thing VCs like to see is rapid growth and that’s the one thing that would kill Mastodon.

I have a better set of interactions here with 5,000 followers than on Twitter with over 100K followers. But I also realize that’s partially due to the niche nature of the service.

The service is also currently not designed for policing that scale of usage.

https://www.ft.com/content/de808736-2e05-4c3b-a53c-55b170ae9efd

@victoriadecapua @joeinwynnewood @shengokai @Quinnae_Moon Yep. And, the way that using Github prirotizes feedback from devs (and dev-adjacent people) over everybody else has been pointed out for years ... yet another reason your concerns about dev responsiveness are on target!

Here's three github threads on quoting::

- original, from 2017: https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/issues/309

- https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/issues/14597#issuecomment-1362907651 (with a great comment from @futurebird )

- https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/issues/20673

title: The RECEPTIO-Rossi Affair, Part I: The Staff

last_post.content:
For those not yet following, Peter Kidd began by noticing disturbing similarities between his own research on his blog and in an exhibit catalog and a monograph published by a (former?) University of Zurich professor: https://mssprovenance.blogspot.com/2022/12/nobody-cares-about-your-blog.html?m=1
And goes on to realize the press that published it has fake staff, fake board, stock photos, fake address, fake emails, but loads of extremely real grant money:
https://mssprovenance.blogspot.com/2022/12/the-receptio-rossi-affair-part-i-staff.html?m=1

title: Making the (Letter) Grade: The Incentive Effects of Mandatory Pass/Fail Courses

last_post.content:
This is interesting!

RT @emollick@twitter.com

What happened when Wellesley College switched to pass/fail grading for first semester students?

It caused students future grades to drop by 23% of a standard deviation, apparently due to lower effort and preparation by students in ungraded courses. https://www.nber.org/papers/w30798

🐦🔗: https://twitter.com/emollick/status/1607395595903471616

title: Large Language Models Encode Clinical Knowledge

last_post.content:
RT @AziziShekoofeh@twitter.com

Excited to share Med-PaLM, a large language model aligned to the medical domain to generate safe and helpful answers.

Our work advances SOTA in 7 medical question-answering tasks, including achieving 67% on MedQA USMLE improving prior work by >17%.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.13138

🐦🔗: https://twitter.com/AziziShekoofeh/status/1607798892892164096

"In this new computer science—if we even call it computer science at all—the machines will be so powerful and already know how to do so many things that the field will look like less of an engineering endeavor and more of an educational one; that is, how to best educate the machine, not unlike the science of how to best educate children in school."

And thus, @gvwilson, will you be vindicated at last!

https://cacm.acm.org/magazines/2023/1/267976-the-end-of-programming/fulltext

If you install the https://www.libraryextension.com/ browser extension, then when you're on a book's page on Amazon it'll show you if your local library has copies, and if so, let you place a hold. It's a beautiful example of a useful little tool.

Last month observed below average air temperatures in the Antarctic. Otherwise, the largest warm anomalies were found in the Northern Hemisphere.

Plot shows zonal-mean surface air temperature anomalies for November 2022, where latitude = x-axis (not scaled by distance) and the temperature anomaly = y-axis. The "flat" appearance at both poles is due to the coarse spatial resolution of the dataset. Data is from GISTEMPv4 at https://data.giss.nasa.gov/gistemp/.

title: She Says Doctors Ignored Her Concerns About Her Pregnancy. For Many Black Women, It’s a Familiar Story.

last_post.content:
She Says Doctors Ignored Her Concerns About Her Pregnancy. For Many Black Women, It’s a Familiar Story.
--

Black women overall are more than twice as likely as white women to have a #stillbirth, according to 2020 #CDC data.

In some states, including #SouthCarolina, #Kansas & #Tennessee, they are around three times as likely to deliver a stillborn baby.

#Parents #babies #health #healthcare #pregnancy

https://www.propublica.org/article/stillbirths-pregnancy-mothers-parents-racial-disparities

title: Informal Government Coercion and The Problem of "Jawboning"

last_post.content: Regarding the Twitter files and, in particular, White House and FBI flagging content/users. When it rises to a 1A violation depends on whether the government used coercion. And what coercion is from a legal standpoint is not always clearcut, particularly due to a somewhat inconsistent line of cases that Genevieve Lakier nicely summarizes here. https://www.lawfareblog.com/informal-government-coercion-and-problem-jawboning

The power [and danger] of story:

Stories that fuel the constant doubt and outrage online only serve to distract us. Whose story wins will depend on how smart we are. Let’s make sense BEFORE we make up stories to tell others.

https://jarche.com/2022/04/the-power-of-story/

#PKMastery #PKM

title: What’s in a PR statement: LastPass breach explained

last_post.content:
Writing more about #LastPassBreach feels like beating a dead horse. But I had a look at the official statement again and it is highly misleading. I felt the need to provide some context that #LastPass is willingly omitting.

“Again, it seems that LastPass attempts to minimize the risk of litigation (hence alerting businesses) while also trying to prevent a public outcry (so not notifying the general public). Priorities…”

https://palant.info/2022/12/26/whats-in-a-pr-statement-lastpass-breach-explained/

title: HIST1900 @Carleton U Winter 2023 with Shawn Graham - The History of the Internet

last_post.content: So my 'history of the internet' class website is more or less built. Comes complete with an #obsidianmd vault for the students, preconfigured with a few useful things. The idea for assessment is built around iterative note-making, and a personal online memex a la 'as we may think'; let their notes develop a networked thinking in a way that mirrors other kinds of networks. Readings are a bit idiosyncratic, but they're just jumping off points, not gospel... https://shawngraham.github.io/hist1900/

For those of you who are as eager to read more about the #Receptiogate affair as I am, here is today’s news instalment, a 5th post by the duped blogger, addressing the issue of plagiarism. As entertaining as this is in all its absurdity, at the heart it is a truly sad and disturbing situation, of course. To be continued, no doubt.

https://mssprovenance.blogspot.com/2022/12/the-receptio-rossi-affair-part-v.html

@hrheingold

Thanks for encouragement. This is the mission we launched with in 1993.

The mission of the Tutor/Mentor Institute (T/MI) is to gather and organize all that
is known about successful non-school tutoring/mentoring programs and apply
that knowledge to expand the availability and enhance the effectiveness of
these services to children throughout the Chicago region.

The entire http://www.tutormentorexchange.net website is a resource library.

There should be versions in every city.

title: Time pressure reduces misinformation discrimination ability but does not alter response bias - Scientific Reports

last_post.content:
Nice to see a new conceptual replication/extension by Sultan et al of our 2020 finding that reducing deliberation makes people more likely to believe false claims (but has no effect on belief in true claims). This is particularly important in the context of social media, where people tend to scroll quickly and not think carefully about the claims they are encountering.

New paper by Sultan et al: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-022-26209-8

Our paper (Bago et al 2020 JEPG): https://psycnet.apa.org/record/2020-00479-001
Ungated pdf: https://psyarxiv.com/29b4j
Summary Tweet thread: https://twitter.com/BenceBago/status/1220099034465144838?s=20

Also relevant is this 2020 paper of ours showing that inceasing reliance on emotion when reading news has the same effect of increasing belief in false news: https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186/s41235-020-00252-3

Nice to see a new conceptual replication/extension by Sultan et al of our 2020 finding that reducing deliberation makes people more likely to believe false claims (but has no effect on belief in true claims). This is particularly important in the context of social media, where people tend to scroll quickly and not think carefully about the claims they are encountering.

title: Tesla stopped reporting its Autopilot safety numbers online. Why?

last_post.content: “Tesla Autopilot crash numbers are far higher than those of similar driver-assistance systems from GM and Ford. To be comparable with Ford’s rate, Tesla ought to have a NHTSA-reported crash total of 70 since last summer. Instead Tesla reported 516 crashes.”https://www.latimes.com/business/story/2022-12-27/tesla-stopped-reporting-autopilot-safety-statistics-online

title: ‎Moderated Content: MC Weekly Update 12/27: Trust and Safety Does Not Take Holidays on Apple Podcasts

last_post.content:
Looking for a podcast to help drown out the in-laws? The latest Moderated Content episode with @evelyndouek is posted! We talk about:

- The Platform Transparency and Accountability Act
- The major breach of LastPass
- A scandal at TikTok
- And, of course, This Week in Musk

https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/mc-weekly-update-12-27-trust-and-safety-does-not-take/id1646510125?i=1000591437662

The Epistemology of Data Science: Mathematics and the Critical Research Agenda on Data Practices
Francois et al 2020-2023

title: Why do tree-based models still outperform deep learning on tabular data?

last_post.content:
Why do tree-based methods work so well with tabular data compared to NNs?

they're less sensitive to bad features
they're not invariant to data rotations
they can easily learn irregular functions

Interesting read from @GaelVaroquaux and co. https://arxiv.org/abs/2207.08815

title: They Called 911 for Help. Police and Prosecutors Used a New Junk Science to Decide They Were Liars.

last_post.content:
They Called 911 for Help. Police and Prosecutors Used a New Junk Science to Decide They Were Liars.
--
People who call 911 don’t know it, but detectives & prosecutors are listening in, ready to assign guilt based on the words they hear.

Some have been wrongfully accused & convicted of murder after someone misinterpreted their call for help, while those who used 911 call analysis against them face little or no consequences.

#Police #911 #FBI #Crime #CriminalJustice

https://www.propublica.org/article/911-call-analysis-fbi-police-courts

Interesting story of how a fake story gets propagated and amplified in mainstream outlets like the WSJ that a university like Stanford is imposing some kind of speech code.

https://mastodon.social/@adriandaub/109577031998660554

(Pasting this link might work as a quote toot?!)

What I especially appreciate about the account is the continuity it shows between what was actually going on at Stanford (spoiler: not a speech code) and what happens in any modern corporation doing brand management…

For the last lab note of 2022, I explore an alternative way of thinking about notifications in the OS of the future. I have a lot more that I should write on this, but here's a start: https://alexanderobenauer.com/labnotes/034/
